action.action-desc: Mr. Sean Patrick Maloney of New York introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a refundable credit against income tax to assist individuals with high residential energy costs.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Home Energy Affordability Tax Relief Act of 2014
or the HEATR Act of 2014 .

section.header: Refundable credit for residential energy costs

subsection.text: Subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to rules of special application) is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

section.header: Refundable credit for residential energy costs

subsection.text: In the case of an individual, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax imposed by this subtitle for the taxable year an amount equal to the lesser of—

paragraph.text: 33 percent of the amount of the taxpayer’s residential energy costs for such taxable year, or

The amount allowable as a credit under subsection (a) for any taxable year shall be reduced (but not below zero) by an amount which bears the same ratio to the amount so allowable (determined without regard to this paragraph) as—

subparagraph.text: the amount (if any) by which the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 (twice such amount in the case of a joint return), bears to

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1), adjusted gross income shall be determined without regard to sections 911, 931, and 933.
The term residential energy costs means the amount paid or incurred by the taxpayer during the taxable year—

subparagraph.text: to any utility for electricity or natural gas used in the principal residence of the taxpayer during the heating season, and
for any qualified fuel for use in the principal residence of the taxpayer but only if such fuel is the primary fuel for heating such residence.
The term principal residence has the meaning given to such term by section 121; except that no ownership requirement shall be imposed.

clause.text: any residence located outside the United States, and
any residence not used as the taxpayer’s principal place of abode throughout the heating season.

paragraph.text: The term heating season means October, November, December, January, February, and March.
The term qualified fuel includes propane, heating oil, kerosene, wood, and wood pellets.

paragraph.header: Individuals paying on level payment basis
paragraph.text: Amounts paid for natural gas under a level payment plan for any period shall be treated as paid for natural gas used during the portion (if any) of the heating season during such period to the extent of the amount charged for natural gas used during such portion of the heating season. A similar rule shall apply to electricity and any qualified fuel.

The application of this section to homeowners associations (as defined in section 528(c)(1)) or members of such associations, and tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations (as defined in section 216), shall be allowed by allocation, apportionment, or otherwise, to the individuals paying, directly or indirectly, for the residential energy cost so incurred.

paragraph.header: Dollar amount in case of joint occupancy
paragraph.text: In the case of a dwelling unit which is the principal residence by 2 or more individuals, the dollar limitation under subsection (a)(2) shall be allocated among such individuals under regulations prescribed by the Secretary.
For purposes of this title, the credit allowed by this section shall be treated as a credit allowed under subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 (relating to refundable credits).

subsection.text: This section shall apply to residential energy costs paid or incurred after the date of the enactment of this section and before April 1, 2016.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (2) of section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by striking or 6428 or and inserting , 6428, 6433, or.
The table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of such Code is amended by adding at the end the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 6433. Refundable credit for residential energy costs..

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act.
